title: Quantum chaos and complexity from string scattering amplitudes
abstract:
We introduce Krylov spread complexity in the context of black hole scattering
by studying highly excited string states (HESS). Krylov complexity
characterizes chaos by quantifying the spread of a state or operator under a
known Hamiltonian. In contrast, quantum field theory often relies on
S-matrices, where the Hamiltonian density becomes non-trivially time-dependent
rendering the computations of complexity in Krylov basis exponentially hard. We
define Krylov spread complexity for scattering amplitudes by analyzing the
distribution of extrema, treating these as eigenvalues of a fictional
Hamiltonian that evolves a thermo-field double state non-trivially. Our
analysis of black hole scattering, through highly excited string states
scattering into two or three tachyons, reveals that the Krylov complexity of
these amplitudes mirrors the behavior of chaotic Hamiltonian evolution, with a
pre-saturation peak indicating chaos. This formalism bridges the concepts of
chaos in scattering and state evolution, offering a framework to distinguish
different scattering processes.
